You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: building approvals, particularly for houses, were bottoming out in all states except western australia, where approvals continued to trend up.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: they noted the sharp differences in performance between sectors and regions of the economy, and the considerable structural change that was occurring, as well as the soft overall conditions in the housing sector and the likelihood of significant fiscal tightening in the next few years.\n                "}]

consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, the forecast pick-up in underlying inflation was now expected to occur a little later than previously expected, mainly as a result of the lower forecast for growth in gdp and downside risks to utilities and administered price inflation in the near term.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions a lower forecast for GDP growth and downside risks to utilities and administered price inflation, indicating a slower-than-expected pick-up in underlying inflation, which suggests a dovish stance."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: a notable exception was japan, where the market was more than 15 per cent lower.\n                "}]

   \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: despite the resumption of growth, there remained significant spare capacity in the advanced economies as evidenced by the high levels of unemployment and low levels of measures of capacity utilisation.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 01:58:01,546 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights significant spare capacity in advanced economies, indicated by high unemployment and low capacity utilization, suggesting a need for accommodative monetary policy."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when 2025-05-04 01:58:07,913 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Reserve Bank of Australia\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: over the past year, resource exports had grown strongly and further growth was in prospect as the production of liquefied natural gas ramped up.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates strong growth in resource exports and further growth prospects, which could lead to higher inflation and justify stricter monetary policy."
}

sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of Australia}} \\label{tb:rba_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, when economic growth is predicted to be low, when cash rate (the goal overnight lending rate) target will be lowered, when inflation is below the inflation target, when the AONIA (the overnight lending rate) is below the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation increases, when economic growth is predicted to be high, when cash rate target will be raised, when inflation is above the inflation target, when the AONIA (aka cash rate) is above the cash rate target. & \nWhen inflation remains unchanged, when the cash rate target remains unchanged, when inflation is at the inflation target, when the cash rate is at the cash rate target. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Government Spending} & \nWhen government spending decreases. & \nWhen government spending increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is “accommodative,” indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & \nUse of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & \nWhen the Australian Dollar appreciates. & \nWhen the Australian Dollar depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy, Commodity, House Prices} & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices decrease. & \nWhen energy, commodities, or home prices increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets} & \nRBA expects subpar inflation, RBA expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & \nRBA expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit decreases or there are positive developments in trade relations, especially with top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen Australia’s trade deficit increases or trade relations worsen, especially concerning top trading partners such as China, Japan, US, and the EU. & \nWhen relating to a foreign nation’s policy with no effect. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor} & \nWhen productivity increases, when unemployment increases. & \nWhen productivity decreases, when unemployment decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Consumer Sentiment} & \nNegative Consumer Sentiment. & \nPositive Consumer Sentiment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Wages} & \nWages decrease. & \nWages increase. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: inflation was significantly higher in the united kingdom, partly reflecting the increase in the vat rate and the depreciation of the pound sterling.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{rba}{eleven} Economic Status, Government Spending, Key Words and Phrases, Dollar Value Change, Energy, Commodity, House Prices, RBA Expectations, Actions, Assets, Foreign Nations, Money Supply, Labor, Consumer Sentiment, Wages.\n\n\n\\textbf{Definitions:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\textit{Economic Status}: A sentence discussing the current state of inflation, unemployment, or overall economic growth, and how these indicators influence monetary policy decisions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Government Spending}: A sentence pertaining to levels of government spending, such as enacting expansionary or contractionary fiscal policy.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the Australian Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Energy/Commodity/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to Energy via changes in prices of energy commodities or the energy sector as a whole, Commodities via precious metals or agricultural goods, or House Prices via single-family homes or the real estate sector as a whole.\n\n    \\item \\textit{RBA Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the cash rate, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Australia and a foreign country. If not discussing Australia we label neutral.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Consumer Sentiment}: A sentence reflecting the general confidence of households regarding future economic conditions.\n\n    \\item \\textit{Wages}: A sentence highlighting wage growth or decline, which impacts inflation and consumer spending\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The AONIA remained below target despite a recent policy change.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Indicates that lower-than-target overnight lending rates suggest an easing stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The RBA’s stance has been accommodative toward recent inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Suggests that the central bank is prioritizing economic support over tightening measures.\n    \n    \\item ``Inflation has proved to be persistent and a challenge, staying above the inflation target even with recent efforts.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Implies that ongoing high inflation may necessitate a tightening of monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Import trade restrictions for China, one of Australia’s key trading partners could lead to supply shortages and higher prices, consequentially increasing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Highlights how external trade barriers can drive inflation upward, justifying stricter policy.\n    \n    \\item ``After consideration, the cash rate target will remain unchanged as of October 2024.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Reflects a decision to maintain the current policy without alteration.\n\n    \\item ``Members recognized that the calibration of this guidance was not precise or straightforward.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Discusses the clarity and formulation of policy guidance rather than actual economic indicators or monetary actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Reserve Bank of
